intro: Paepalanthus heterocaulon, commonly known as the Andean buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It is a member of the Polygonaceae family, known for its distinctive, palmate leaves and showy yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in high-altitude regions, often in rocky or alpine environments. It has a short stem with a rosette of leaves and produces small, clustered flowers that bloom in the spring. Due to its unique morphology and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
